title: Materials Down as Saudi Attacks Weigh on Risk — Materials Roundup
text:
Producers of metals and other raw materials fell as drone attacks on Saudi Arabian oil facilities slowed a rotation into the high-risk sector.

Shares of Nucor fell after the steelmaker warned that third-quarter earnings would trail Wall Street estimates, citing slowing demand from automotive and agricultural-machinery customers.

Gold futures, which are often purchased as a hedge against geopolitical and market instability, regained most of last week's losses.

The Justice Department said it charged a former and two current JPMorgan Chase precious-metals traders for their alleged participation in a racketeering conspiracy involving precious metals futures contracts over an eight-year period. Monday's loss of risk appetites follows a strong opening to September for the materials sector and other risky niches.

"There has been a clear shift toward risk-on positioning over the past few weeks," said Bob Doll, chief equity strategist at money manager Nuveen Investments. "We would cite several causes, including some better economic data, an easing of trade tensions, de-escalation in Hong Kong, receding risks of a hard Brexit and an easier monetary policy backdrop."
